title: Ava 4A
text:
The Ava 4A was a low power <a href="flat-four">flat-four</a> (<a href="boxer%20engine">boxer engine</a>) developed for very light aircraft in <a href="France">France</a> in the 1930s. It was used by several prototypes and at least one production series.
Design and development.
Marcel Violet was a French racing driver who designed his own two-cylinder, <a href="two-stroke%20engine">two-stroke engine</a>s. He also designed a two stroke <a href="horizontally%20opposed">horizontally opposed</a> <a href="flat-four">flat-four</a>, which was built under licence at "L'agence general moteurs "Ava"" by Jean Aubry of the "Société J. Thibault, G Aubry et Cie", alloy metal specialists, as the Ava 4A. It only produced and was intended to power small, low cost, single seat aircraft, replacing the aging <a href="Anzani">Anzani</a>s and completing with the French <a href="Mengin%20Type%20B">Mengin Type B</a> and the older <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> <a href="Bristol%20Cherub">Bristol Cherub</a> engines.
The Ava 4A was on display at the November 1936 Paris Salon. It powered several prototypes and also the forty-six examples of the series production variant of the <a href="Farman%20Moustique">Farman Moustique</a>, the F.451.
Survivors.
A 4A-00 survives in a private collection and is sometimes exhibited on loan.
